values.title: Nightly Build as of May 25th Appears to be Broekn

content.raw:

values.title: Thumb goes through the vehicle's steering wheel

content.raw: The robot's thumb (and possibly other digits) seem to sometimes go through the steering wheel. This causes the robot to loose grip.
content.html: The robot's thumb (and possibly other digits) seem to sometimes go through the steering wheel. This causes the robot to loose grip.

values.title: Collision Issue With Hand/Nozzle in VRC 3

content.raw:
I have seen issues with collision detection between the hand and the hose.  It seems that the hand passes through the model, I'm not sure if a specific action instantiates it, other than grasping, but I'll try to reproduce it.  If I do I'll edit this post/reply with more info.

Here is an image of what I am talking about.

![Hand_Hose Collision Issue](https://www.theroboticschallenge.org/_SiteImages/Discussions/Issue_HoseCollision_1.jpg)

<launch>

values.title: Drifting while sitting in vehicle

content.raw:
Atlas drifts quite a bit when just sitting in the vehicle.  This was not seen in 2.6.1, but is seen in the nightly build.  It drifts fast enough that the robot will fall over or drift out in about 1 minute.  It can be reproduced by teleporting in to the vehicle in vrc_task_1.  Note that this is different than the minor issue where the robot's left foot sometime catches when teleporting.

```
#!shell

rostopic pub --once /drc_world/robot_enter_car geometry_msgs/Pose '{}'
rostopic pub -1 /atlas/mode std_msgs/String -- nominal

```
content.html:
Atlas drifts quite a bit when just sitting in the vehicle. This was not seen in 2.6.1, but is seen in the nightly build. It drifts fast enough that the robot will fall over or drift out in about 1 minute. It can be reproduced by teleporting in to the vehicle in vrc_task_1. Note that this is different than the minor issue where the robot's left foot sometime catches when teleporting.

rostopic pub --once /drc_world/robot_enter_car geometry_msgs/Pose '{}'
rostopic pub -1 /atlas/mode std_msgs/String -- nominal

values.title: Standpipe/hose state machine bug

content.raw:
Summary:
The standpipe/hose state machine refuses to create a link if the initial link is broken.

Detail:
I've written a little gazebo plugin to automatically attach the hose. It just uses SetWorldPose() to position the coupling:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MRVrvdsRUAs
... this works just fine and vrc_score reports that the standpipe/hose link has been made.

However if I counter-rotate the hose and it comes off, it cannot ever go back on - even with a dozen re-attachements:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wHe-3kmDn9I

To reiterate: my plugin works 100% of time on the first connection and 0% of the time on subsequent connections

I assume that there is a bug in the standpipe/hose state machine.

In addition to fixing this bug, can you please report when it will be fixed on the cloud sim instances?
content.html:
Summary: The standpipe/hose state machine refuses to create a link if the initial link is broken.

Detail: I've written a little gazebo plugin to automatically attach the hose. It just uses SetWorldPose() to position the coupling: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MRVrvdsRUAs ... this works just fine and vrc_score reports that the standpipe/hose link has been made.

However if I counter-rotate the hose and it comes off, it cannot ever go back on - even with a dozen re-attachements: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wHe-3kmDn9I

To reiterate: my plugin works 100% of time on the first connection and 0% of the time on subsequent connections

I assume that there is a bug in the standpipe/hose state machine.

In addition to fixing this bug, can you please report when it will be fixed on the cloud sim instances?

values.title: Controller Synchronization Errors

content.raw:
We have our controllers running at 500hz, and I thought everything was going well using the controller synchronization tutorial here: http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/drcsim/2.6/controller_synchronization

However, after looking at this more closely, it seems that there may be some issues, or I am understanding the tutorial wrong. 

When I run the tutorial code as provided, gazebo does not spit out any errors. However, for a 500Hz controller (like the one in the example, as well as ours) the ``ac.desired_controller_period_ms = 5;`` should actually be 2ms, not 5ms. If I change the value from 5 to 2, I get errors once about every 3 or 4 seconds of the following: 

``AtlasPlugin controller synchronization timedout: message lost or controller stopped.``

So it looks like there is both an issue with the tutorial, as well as the support in the simulator for this functionality.
content.html:
We have our controllers running at 500hz, and I thought everything was going well using the controller synchronization tutorial here: http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/drcsim/2.6/controller_synchronization

However, after looking at this more closely, it seems that there may be some issues, or I am understanding the tutorial wrong.

When I run the tutorial code as provided, gazebo does not spit out any errors. However, for a 500Hz controller (like the one in the example, as well as ours) the ac.desired_controller_period_ms = 5; should actually be 2ms, not 5ms. If I change the value from 5 to 2, I get errors once about every 3 or 4 seconds of the following:

AtlasPlugin controller synchronization timedout: message lost or controller stopped.

So it looks like there is both an issue with the tutorial, as well as the support in the simulator for this functionality.

values.title: Inertia calculation for fixed joints incorrect

content.raw:
This bug report assumes that the moment of inertia specified in a URDF is with respect to the coordinate frame of the <inertia> tag (at the center of mass).

There is a bug in the URDF parser that reduces fixed joints ("parser_urdf.cc", [URDF2Gazebo::ReduceFixedJoints](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/9a4c0147feb9538375e2dd5bec39e0b353f05556/gazebo/sdf/interface/parser_urdf.cc#cl-898).  In particular, it calls the method [URDF2Gazebo::ReduceInertialToParent](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/9a4c0147feb9538375e2dd5bec39e0b353f05556/gazebo/sdf/interface/parser_urdf.cc#cl-1825).

This method appears to assume that the moments of inertia are written with respect to their *link origins* and not the center of mass.  The inertia of the child link is translated using the origin transform of the fixed joint, only.

The correct method is to:
1) First calculate the new center of mass position
2) Transform both parent and child inertias to that new CM
3) Then sum the two inertias.

Another, more roundabout approach (that makes use of the current code) is to:
1) Transform both parent and child inertias to the parent link origin.
2) Sum the two inertias using dMassAdd
3) Transform the summed inertia to the new CM

Note, for the DRC, this primarily effects the Sandia hand URDF.  The base Atlas does not have any links with significant mass attached via fixed joints.  On each Sandia hand, the hand, palm, and 4x finger base links are all joined by fixed joints.

The resulting inertia in Gazebo is significantly larger than the true inertia (by a factor of 2-3) which noticeably impacts the simulation of the robot.
content.html:
This bug report assumes that the moment of inertia specified in a URDF is with respect to the coordinate frame of the <inertia> tag (at the center of mass).

There is a bug in the URDF parser that reduces fixed joints ("parser_urdf.cc", URDF2Gazebo::ReduceFixedJoints. In particular, it calls the method URDF2Gazebo::ReduceInertialToParent.

This method appears to assume that the moments of inertia are written with respect to their link origins and not the center of mass. The inertia of the child link is translated using the origin transform of the fixed joint, only.

The correct method is to: 1) First calculate the new center of mass position 2) Transform both parent and child inertias to that new CM 3) Then sum the two inertias.

Another, more roundabout approach (that makes use of the current code) is to: 1) Transform both parent and child inertias to the parent link origin. 2) Sum the two inertias using dMassAdd 3) Transform the summed inertia to the new CM

Note, for the DRC, this primarily effects the Sandia hand URDF. The base Atlas does not have any links with significant mass attached via fixed joints. On each Sandia hand, the hand, palm, and 4x finger base links are all joined by fixed joints.

The resulting inertia in Gazebo is significantly larger than the true inertia (by a factor of 2-3) which noticeably impacts the simulation of the robot.

values.title: undefined location of sandia hand contact sensors

content.raw:
The sensors in the fingers are numbered 1-12 and then with a second batch from 1-6 in the API:

http://gazebosim.org/wiki/DRC/UserGuide#ROS_APIs

Namely:

http://gazebosim.org/w/images/5/57/Sandiahand_drc_slide.pdf

The driver outputs a vector of 18 values - so its undefined which are which are which.
Is it 1-12 followed by 1-6  <OR> 1-6 followed by 1-12?

(The sensors in the palm are number 1-32 which presumable match the spec)

values.title: BDI single-step fails when orientation not close to zero

content.raw:
If the robot has been moved and is no longer facing in the same generatl direction that it started at, sending an AtlasSimInterfaceCommand with a behavior equal to STEP will cause the robot to freeze up and fall over.  This does not happen if the robot has been moved but is still facing the same general direction that it started at.

The attached script can be used to re-produce this behavior.  Running the following commands will cause the robot to turn left using MULTI-STEP and then attempt to take a SINGLE-STEP (with the same pose as the last footstep that was executed using MULTI-STEP):
roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_sandia_hands.launch
./walk_test.py turn multi
./walk_test.py turn single

Running the following commands will cause the robot to walk straight using MULTI-STEP and then successfully take a SINGLE-STEP:
roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_sandia_hands.launch
./walk_test.py straight multi
./walk_test.py straight single
content.html:
If the robot has been moved and is no longer facing in the same generatl direction that it started at, sending an AtlasSimInterfaceCommand with a behavior equal to STEP will cause the robot to freeze up and fall over. This does not happen if the robot has been moved but is still facing the same general direction that it started at.

The attached script can be used to re-produce this behavior. Running the following commands will cause the robot to turn left using MULTI-STEP and then attempt to take a SINGLE-STEP (with the same pose as the last footstep that was executed using MULTI-STEP): roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_sandia_hands.launch ./walk_test.py turn multi ./walk_test.py turn single

Running the following commands will cause the robot to walk straight using MULTI-STEP and then successfully take a SINGLE-STEP: roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_sandia_hands.launch ./walk_test.py straight multi ./walk_test.py straight single

values.title: Change scoring messages to refer to gates numbered from 1

content.raw:
The messages in /vrc_score refer to gates numbered from 0.  The gates are numbered in the world from 1.

To avoid confusion, change the message to be 1-based.

values.title: Consider relaxing check for valve turn

content.raw:
We've had a report that in V3, the score did not increment from 3 to 4 after rotating the valve.  A potential cause (not yet confirmed) is that the hose became unscrewed enough (e.g., due to gravity) after getting the 3rd point and before turning the valve.

This problem can be avoided by relaxing [the check](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/826552d800ba1fd84554b7f46f9757249f663565/ros/atlas_msgs/VRCScoringPlugin.cc?at=default#cl-600) in the scoring code.
content.html:
We've had a report that in V3, the score did not increment from 3 to 4 after rotating the valve. A potential cause (not yet confirmed) is that the hose became unscrewed enough (e.g., due to gravity) after getting the 3rd point and before turning the valve.

This problem can be avoided by relaxing the check in the scoring code.

values.title: Potential VRC3 AddJoint issue

content.raw:
Since we are winding down to the last bug fixes, I thought I might mention something that may or may not be a bug. I can't say, because, to be honest, we haven't been
able to extensively test it.

If AddJoint uses the current world poses when it adds a joint between the "spout" and
the "coupling", this may lock in a misalignment of the coupling. As the coupling is screwed in, this misalignment may cause a jam and prevent further turning. Effectively, the misaligned coupling sweeps out a cone as it rotates, and this cone needs to fit into the spout hole.

This is not a bug if:

a) the currently required alignment tolerance eliminates the problem (can't tell).

b) AddJoint somehow perfectly aligns the coordinate frames of the hose and the coupling and then makes the joint.

I would request b) to be implemented if it is not already.

Thanks,
Chris
content.html:
Since we are winding down to the last bug fixes, I thought I might mention something that may or may not be a bug. I can't say, because, to be honest, we haven't been able to extensively test it.

If AddJoint uses the current world poses when it adds a joint between the "spout" and the "coupling", this may lock in a misalignment of the coupling. As the coupling is screwed in, this misalignment may cause a jam and prevent further turning. Effectively, the misaligned coupling sweeps out a cone as it rotates, and this cone needs to fit into the spout hole.

This is not a bug if:

a) the currently required alignment tolerance eliminates the problem (can't tell).

b) AddJoint somehow perfectly aligns the coordinate frames of the hose and the coupling and then makes the joint.

I would request b) to be implemented if it is not already.

Thanks, Chris

values.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
Here is a sequence of laser scan timestamps from VRC running on the SoftLayer machines:

~~~

header-timestamp  simulation-time-at-receipt  wall-time-at-receipt

  145.2350  145.2450   29.2710

  145.2350  145.2730   29.3160

  145.2680  145.3070   29.3710

  145.3010  145.3410   29.4260

  145.3330  145.3450   29.4320

  145.3440  145.3730   29.4800

  145.3750  145.4060   29.5340

  145.4060  145.4380   29.5890

  145.4370  145.4440   29.5990

  145.4370  145.4710   29.6450

  145.4690  145.5050   29.7030

  145.5090  145.5370   29.7580

  145.5390  145.5450   29.7720

  145.5390  145.5700   29.8160

  145.5690  145.6080   29.8810

  145.6090  145.6380   29.9330

  145.6390  145.6440   29.9430

  145.6390  145.6700   29.9890

  145.6690  145.7030   30.0470

  145.7090  145.7370   30.1060

~~~

Note that we start with duplicate header timestamps received at different times.
This occurs again at 145.4370, 145.5390, and 145.6390.

The scans with timestamps 145.2350 are different. I did not check the others.

The user guide says the header time stamp is when the scan started. If this were true, the header timestamps should be regular with gaps for missed samples.
This is clearly not the case in this plot of the difference between adjacent header timestamps.
[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/laser-times1.png]()

The difference between the receipt time (in sim_time units) and the header time stamp should be at least the scan time (25ms). It is not.
[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/laser-times2.png]()

Is this a problem with the GPU implementation?
Are the scans getting time stamped after a variable delay in GPU processing?

values.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Contacts between Atlas' thighs and pelvis collision models and the polaris vehicle seem extremely slippery. Just sitting in the car and not performing any motions, there is enough drift to cause the robot to move from right in front of the steering wheel to the middle of the front seat in about 40 seconds.

I thought this issue was fixed by the mud_seat. Could this be due to the fact that we teleport the robot next to the car to avoid walking over all the time? Is it possible that the mud plugin does not get enabled when you teleport? How do I check if it is enabled?

Attached are graphs of the robot's x and y position over time from two different runs. As you can see, the robot drifts about 9 cm in 30 seconds. Videos corresponding to these runs can be found here:
http://www.ihmc.us/files/ihmc_files/atlas_seat_drift.webm
http://www.ihmc.us/files/ihmc_files/atlas_seat_drift2.webm

Note that the robot started right in front of the steering wheel at the start of the sim and had already drifted to the positions at the start of the videos before we could start recording video.

This occurs with the DRCSim 1.8.5 release and the Gazebo 2.6.4 release, so it's not the same version as [#305](#!/osrf/drcsim/issue/305/drifting-while-sitting-in-vehicle), which is why I'm reopening this issue.

values.title: Joint wrapping problem with two firehose links

content.raw: The first axes of joint_07 and joint_14 in vrc_firehose_long have limits of [0,3.14] and [-3.14,0] radians, respectively. There's currently an issue with the universal joints in gazebo ([gazebo 724](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/724/universal-joint-getangle-wraps-at-pi-pi)), that they wrap at [-pi, pi]. It's bad to have the joint limits near pi since a very small joint violation can cause wrapping, which will cause the joint to fully invert, as shown in [this video](https://vimeo.com/67788168).
content.html: The first axes of joint_07 and joint_14 in vrc_firehose_long have limits of [0,3.14] and [-3.14,0] radians, respectively. There's currently an issue with the universal joints in gazebo (gazebo 724), that they wrap at [-pi, pi]. It's bad to have the joint limits near pi since a very small joint violation can cause wrapping, which will cause the joint to fully invert, as shown in this video.

Reported by @faller in the [forum](https://www.theroboticschallenge.org/forum/default.aspx?Function_fst=ViewThread&ThreadID_fin=319):

Images and Laser aren't created at fixed and reliable rates. When subscribed 2 days ago I got 40Hz laser, 30Hz cameras.

rostopic hz /sandia_hands/r_hand/camera/left/image_raw

values.title: Problem with BDI Step Mode

content.raw:
I have found that the drcsim robot instantly freezes when I enter BDI step control mode under certain circumstances. First, the circumstances in which it works successfully
* If I start with zero heading, do dynamic walking, and either maintain the zero heading, or turn during dynamic walking then turn again back to a zero heading, I can reenter step mode (qual 1 fits this pattern)
* If I use step mode to turn to a different heading, then do dynamic walking along that same heading, then stop, I can reenter step mode (ex. step to .78 heading, begin dynamic walking at .78 heading, then stop and reenter stepping mode still at .78 heading)
* If I use step mode to turn to a different heading, then do dynamic walking, in which I turn, but then turn back to end up at the same heading at which I last finished step mode, I can reenter step mode (ex. step to .78 rad heading, begin dynamic walking, turn to 1.57 heading, then turn back to .78 heading, then stop and reenter stepping mode)

However, if I do the following, the robot instantly freezes and falls over
* Start with stepping and finish on any heading, do dynamic walking and turn to a different heading, then attempt to step
*  Ex.  Start with 0 heading, dynamic walk to .78 heading, stop and attempt stepping with instant fail
*  Ex. Start by stepping to .78 heading, dynamic walk to 0 heading, stop and attempt stepping with instant fail
*  Ex. Start directly into dynamic walking, turn to any non-zero heading, stop and attempt stepping with instant fail

It appears to me that the stepping routine remembers its previous heading, and the robot can only reenter step mode if it is at the same heading as it was when it previously ended step mode. This also seems to apply even when the robot never entered step mode after starting the sim

When this error occurs, there are no warning message from the AtlasSimInterfaceState error flag, or the status flags for behavior feedback, walk feedback, or step feedback. The behavior feedback flag simply goes to 256 instantly. I have examined the step data I command and it is perfectly sensible in each case that results in falling. Note: I am able to reenter step mode at any heading. It just has to be a heading I previously achieved by rotating in step mode. Even if the steps were not well positioned, I would expect the robot to attempt the step and fail, rather than just instantly going stiff and falling.

At this point the only work around I can see is to ensure that if I try to enter step mode, my heading is the same as the last time I was in step mode, or if this is the first time in step mode, my heading must be zero.
Obviously I'd like to be able to enter step mode at an arbitrary heading after dynamic walking

Hopefully this can be fixed easily, since the nature of the error is so specific

I have tested this with the latest version of the drcsim software released today.
content.html:
I have found that the drcsim robot instantly freezes when I enter BDI step control mode under certain circumstances. First, the circumstances in which it works successfully If I start with zero heading, do dynamic walking, and either maintain the zero heading, or turn during dynamic walking then turn again back to a zero heading, I can reenter step mode (qual 1 fits this pattern) If I use step mode to turn to a different heading, then do dynamic walking along that same heading, then stop, I can reenter step mode (ex. step to .78 heading, begin dynamic walking at .78 heading, then stop and reenter stepping mode still at .78 heading) * If I use step mode to turn to a different heading, then do dynamic walking, in which I turn, but then turn back to end up at the same heading at which I last finished step mode, I can reenter step mode (ex. step to .78 rad heading, begin dynamic walking, turn to 1.57 heading, then turn back to .78 heading, then stop and reenter stepping mode)

However, if I do the following, the robot instantly freezes and falls over Start with stepping and finish on any heading, do dynamic walking and turn to a different heading, then attempt to step Ex. Start with 0 heading, dynamic walk to .78 heading, stop and attempt stepping with instant fail Ex. Start by stepping to .78 heading, dynamic walk to 0 heading, stop and attempt stepping with instant fail Ex. Start directly into dynamic walking, turn to any non-zero heading, stop and attempt stepping with instant fail

It appears to me that the stepping routine remembers its previous heading, and the robot can only reenter step mode if it is at the same heading as it was when it previously ended step mode. This also seems to apply even when the robot never entered step mode after starting the sim

When this error occurs, there are no warning message from the AtlasSimInterfaceState error flag, or the status flags for behavior feedback, walk feedback, or step feedback. The behavior feedback flag simply goes to 256 instantly. I have examined the step data I command and it is perfectly sensible in each case that results in falling. Note: I am able to reenter step mode at any heading. It just has to be a heading I previously achieved by rotating in step mode. Even if the steps were not well positioned, I would expect the robot to attempt the step and fail, rather than just instantly going stiff and falling.

At this point the only work around I can see is to ensure that if I try to enter step mode, my heading is the same as the last time I was in step mode, or if this is the first time in step mode, my heading must be zero. Obviously I'd like to be able to enter step mode at an arbitrary heading after dynamic walking

Hopefully this can be fixed easily, since the nature of the error is so specific

I have tested this with the latest version of the drcsim software released today.

content.raw:
Now that gazebo has stopped crashing from my previous issue, I can run the DRC driving simulation program I have been working on for my project. The VRC cheats command seems to work in allowing the development aids, as the wheels can now turn when it is run.

content.html:
When building sdformat/sdf-1.4 + gazebo/gazebo_1.9 + drcsim/rml, there are lots of warnings from parsing the URDF (below is a sample from launching atlas_utils/vrc_task_1.launch). Everything seems to work fine, so these warnings should be removed.

I'm not sure whether the fix belongs in drcsim or in sdformat.

values.title: sandia-hands simple_grasp.py change in nightly builds

content.raw:
The syntax for simple_grasp.py has changed in the nightly builds of sandia-hand so that it now requires an argument `left` or `right`.

So the nightly builds of drcsim have some [failing tests](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/drcsim-default-gazebo-default-performance-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/114/testReport/).
content.html:
The syntax for simple_grasp.py has changed in the nightly builds of sandia-hand so that it now requires an argument left or right.

So the nightly builds of drcsim have some failing tests.

values.title: Update robot model to match real atlas

content.raw:
Now the real robot is available, it would be nice if the simulation matches the real robot. As far as we know, the weight of the simulated robot is in the ~90kg range while the real robot is around 150 kg. 

Parameters that should be based on the real robot include
* mass
* Center of mass locations
* inertia parameters
* friction coefficients
* joint limits
* actuator limits (torque - speed curve)

For model based controllers having the correct information is very important. When the competition started, there was talk of NIST validating the robot models, it would be nice if they can make proper measurements on a real Atlas instead of relying on the CAD models.
content.html:
Now the real robot is available, it would be nice if the simulation matches the real robot. As far as we know, the weight of the simulated robot is in the ~90kg range while the real robot is around 150 kg.

Parameters that should be based on the real robot include mass Center of mass locations inertia parameters friction coefficients joint limits actuator limits (torque - speed curve)

For model based controllers having the correct information is very important. When the competition started, there was talk of NIST validating the robot models, it would be nice if they can make proper measurements on a real Atlas instead of relying on the CAD models.

values.title: Update gazebo to match current API for sensors, hands, and robot

content.raw:
To facilitate development, and increase the utility of Gazebo/drcsim  the interfaces should match the APIs being used by the actual robot.

From training at BDI, there are differences between the API developed for VRC.  This was understandable, but going forward having a consistent API is important to minimize the code changes and facilitate rapid testing.
content.html:
To facilitate development, and increase the utility of Gazebo/drcsim the interfaces should match the APIs being used by the actual robot.

From training at BDI, there are differences between the API developed for VRC. This was understandable, but going forward having a consistent API is important to minimize the code changes and facilitate rapid testing.

values.title: Gains don't match between simulator and Atlas hardware

content.raw:
The gains don't match between the simulator and the Atlas hardware.  One example is that the various arm position gains in the simulator range from 50-2000.  The arm position gains on the Atlas hardware range from 5-20.

Another example is the gains outside of the default PID gains.  The Atlas hardware has gains of ff_const, ff_f_d, ff_qd, ff_qd_d, k_f_p, k_qd_p, k_q_i and k_q_p.  Three of these correspond roughly to the PID gains, the other 5 are not simulated.
content.html:
The gains don't match between the simulator and the Atlas hardware. One example is that the various arm position gains in the simulator range from 50-2000. The arm position gains on the Atlas hardware range from 5-20.

Another example is the gains outside of the default PID gains. The Atlas hardware has gains of ff_const, ff_f_d, ff_qd, ff_qd_d, k_f_p, k_qd_p, k_q_i and k_q_p. Three of these correspond roughly to the PID gains, the other 5 are not simulated.

values.title: Remove `k_effort` from `atlas_msgs` to match `AtlasRobotInterface`
Fix topic names to match hardware

content.raw:
There are a few topic names that don't match between the simulator and hardware.  In particular all of the image data topics on the hardware don't have /camera in the topics names.  A couple of examples:

Hardware:
/sandia_hands/l_hand/left/image_raw 
/multisense_sl/left/image_rect_color

Simulator:
/sandia_hands/l_hand/camera/left/image_raw
/multisense_sl/camera/left/image_rect_color
content.html:
There are a few topic names that don't match between the simulator and hardware. In particular all of the image data topics on the hardware don't have /camera in the topics names. A couple of examples:

Hardware: /sandia_hands/l_hand/left/image_raw /multisense_sl/left/image_rect_color

Simulator: /sandia_hands/l_hand/camera/left/image_raw /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_rect_color

values.title: Suggestion - create behavior library to replace libAtlasSimInterface.so

content.raw: Since the old libAtlasSimInterface.so won't work with the new Atlas model, one idea would be to drop libAtlasSimInterface.so.  It could be replaced by a behavior library.  Rather than trying to accurately control the robot during walk/step/stand/manipulate behaviors, just approximate the behaviors.  Walking might hold the robot upright while moving the legs to the commanded x/y positions.  The robot would end up in roughly the same place, but it wouldn't be done in the same way.
content.html: Since the old libAtlasSimInterface.so won't work with the new Atlas model, one idea would be to drop libAtlasSimInterface.so. It could be replaced by a behavior library. Rather than trying to accurately control the robot during walk/step/stand/manipulate behaviors, just approximate the behaviors. Walking might hold the robot upright while moving the legs to the commanded x/y positions. The robot would end up in roughly the same place, but it wouldn't be done in the same way.

values.title: Remove hardcoded Atlas model from DRC practice task worlds

content.raw: Looking at the DRC practice task .world files, the Atlas model is hardcoded into them. This makes it cumbersome to modify them to use another Atlas model (or another robot altogether, which should be useful for Track A teams) and essentially forces users to copy world files and modify them. Given how model files can be included in each other and the general focus on modularity and flexibilty for Gazebo, it should certainly be possible to provide a better solution.
content.html: Looking at the DRC practice task .world files, the Atlas model is hardcoded into them. This makes it cumbersome to modify them to use another Atlas model (or another robot altogether, which should be useful for Track A teams) and essentially forces users to copy world files and modify them. Given how model files can be included in each other and the general focus on modularity and flexibilty for Gazebo, it should certainly be possible to provide a better solution.

values.title: atlas_v3_v1_sandia model blows up where old one doesn't

content.raw:
When we invoke our controller to start sending commands, in this case STAND, the new 

```
#!c++
roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_v3_with_v1_inertia_sandia_hands.launch
```
"blows up", where the original doesn't.
```
#!c++

  roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_sandia_hands.launch
```
Attached are two bag files.  The atlas_v1*.bag is from sending commands to old version, and we get the expected result (nothing since it's already in stand on start).

Replaying the command outputs from that bag into the new version blows up.  See atlas_v3_v1*.bag.

Replaying into original works as expected.

values.title: MultiSense description missing calibration links+joints

content.raw:
The multisense description maintained in drcsim does not match [the one for the real sensor](https://bitbucket.org/crl/multisense_ros/src/5176464640ad9decebc44a2fdc1d7eab80765240/multisense_description/urdf/multisense.urdf?at=default). The most significant difference is that the drcsim one has all the {pre,post}_spindle_cal_{x,y,z,roll,pitch,yaw} links+joints missing which causes loss of calibration when using the entire robot model for the real robot (see lines 30 to 143 in the CRL MultiSense description).

Edit:
The sensor specifications are outdated as well - cameras should be 1024x544 and the LIDAR fov should be 270 and not 180.
content.html:
The multisense description maintained in drcsim does not match the one for the real sensor. The most significant difference is that the drcsim one has all the {pre,post}spindle_cal{x,y,z,roll,pitch,yaw} links+joints missing which causes loss of calibration when using the entire robot model for the real robot (see lines 30 to 143 in the CRL MultiSense description).

Edit: The sensor specifications are outdated as well - cameras should be 1024x544 and the LIDAR fov should be 270 and not 180.

values.title: Collada files do not follow collada specification, id attributes are not unique

content.raw:
According to the collada specification (http://www.khronos.org/files/collada_schema_1_4) id attributes are unique within the document

<xs:attribute name="id" type="xs:ID">
						<xs:annotation>
							<xs:documentation>
							The id attribute is a text string containing the unique identifier of this element. This value 
							must be unique within the instance document. Optional attribute.
							</xs:documentation>
						</xs:annotation>
					</xs:attribute>

Our collada importer assumes this behavior holds and cannot load the models if this is not the case. We changed the DAE files to correspond to the spec and they work fine then. I've attached the changed files.
content.html:
According to the collada specification (http://www.khronos.org/files/collada_schema_1_4) id attributes are unique within the document

<xs:attribute name="id" type="xs:ID"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> The id attribute is a text string containing the unique identifier of this element. This value must be unique within the instance document. Optional attribute. </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:attribute>

Our collada importer assumes this behavior holds and cannot load the models if this is not the case. We changed the DAE files to correspond to the spec and they work fine then. I've attached the changed files.

values.title: Atlas model: Issue with the torque limits

content.raw:
I think there are some errors concerning the torque limits for the Atlas model.
For example, the knee max torque is 220Nm while the ankle pitch max torque is 700Nm, which sounds lowly probable.
Also the arm joint max torques are higher than the ones published by Boston Dynamics.
For example, the shoulder pitch max torque is 212Nm in the simulation model, while BDI gives a min torque of -75Nm and a max torque of 93Nm.

It'd be awesome if you could check the different joint maximum torques.

Regards,
Sylvain
content.html:
I think there are some errors concerning the torque limits for the Atlas model. For example, the knee max torque is 220Nm while the ankle pitch max torque is 700Nm, which sounds lowly probable. Also the arm joint max torques are higher than the ones published by Boston Dynamics. For example, the shoulder pitch max torque is 212Nm in the simulation model, while BDI gives a min torque of -75Nm and a max torque of 93Nm.

It'd be awesome if you could check the different joint maximum torques.

Regards, Sylvain

values.title: Atlas SIM behavior feedback not working

content.raw:
While the robot changes from behaviors STAND to WALK, STAND to STEP, etc. The topic /atlas/atlas_sim_interface_state should be publishing this changes in "tran_from_behavior_index" and "trans_to_behavior_index" however they are always "-1" (blue and red color). 

The topic /atlas/atlas_sim_interface_state/current­_index publishes the changes in the current behavior (pink color), however the behavior_feedback should keep track of the previous behavior (from) and the target behavior (to).

[Behavior feedback not working](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MFy8XcE7E0)
content.html:
While the robot changes from behaviors STAND to WALK, STAND to STEP, etc. The topic /atlas/atlas_sim_interface_state should be publishing this changes in "tran_from_behavior_index" and "trans_to_behavior_index" however they are always "-1" (blue and red color).

The topic /atlas/atlas_sim_interface_state/current­_index publishes the changes in the current behavior (pink color), however the behavior_feedback should keep track of the previous behavior (from) and the target behavior (to).

Behavior feedback not working

values.title: Problem building with catkin_make_isolated --install

content.raw:
If you invoke `catkin_make_isolated --install` in a fresh workspace (it behaves differently if `catkin_make_isolated` was previously invoked), it will fail with the following message:
~~~
CMake Error at /home/scpeters/ws/drcsim/install_isolated/share/drcsim_gazebo_plugins/cmake/drcsim_gazebo_pluginsConfig.cmake:130 (message):
  Project 'drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins' tried to find library
  'DRCVehiclePlugin'.  The library is neither a target nor built/installed
  properly.  Did you compile project 'drcsim_gazebo_plugins'? Did you
  find_package() it before the subdirectory containing its code is included?
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /home/scpeters/ws/drcsim/install_isolated/share/catkin/cmake/catkinConfig.cmake:72 (find_package)
  CMakeLists.txt:7 (find_package)


-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
~~~
With `catkin_make_isolated`, it gets placed in `devel_isolated/drcsim_gazebo_plugins/lib`, whereas with `--install` it gets placed in `install_isolated/lib/drcsim_gazebo_plugins/plugins`. I'm working on a patch.
content.html:
If you invoke catkin_make_isolated --install in a fresh workspace (it behaves differently if catkin_make_isolated was previously invoked), it will fail with the following message:

  properly.  Did you compile project 'drcsim_gazebo_plugins'? Did you
  find_package() it before the subdirectory containing its code is included?
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /home/scpeters/ws/drcsim/install_isolated/share/catkin/cmake/catkinConfig.cmake:72 (find_package)

With catkin_make_isolated, it gets placed in devel_isolated/drcsim_gazebo_plugins/lib, whereas with --install it gets placed in install_isolated/lib/drcsim_gazebo_plugins/plugins. I'm working on a patch.

values.title: Use a more stable and precise physics engine for the Atlas simulation, preferably based on a Featherstone algorithm

content.raw:
The current ODE physics engine is not really suited for the kind of precision we would like to see from  the simulation environment. For example, velocity measurements can be noisy and downright wrong when links are in contact. Furthermore, the simulation is very unstable and tends to explode very quickly, especially using the V3 model.

For our own simulation environment we use a Featherstone algorithm, that is much more stable then the ODE engine in our experience. It would be nice if we can use the features that Gazebo provides (multi-contact dynamics) over our own simulation environment.
content.html:
The current ODE physics engine is not really suited for the kind of precision we would like to see from the simulation environment. For example, velocity measurements can be noisy and downright wrong when links are in contact. Furthermore, the simulation is very unstable and tends to explode very quickly, especially using the V3 model.

For our own simulation environment we use a Featherstone algorithm, that is much more stable then the ODE engine in our experience. It would be nice if we can use the features that Gazebo provides (multi-contact dynamics) over our own simulation environment.

values.title: Race condition on start with scoring plugin

content.raw:
With 3.1.0, I see this in the startup sequence when running `roslaunch drcsim_gazebo vrc_task_3.launch`:

~~~
[ INFO] [1382118350.430409299]: Starting robot with BDI standing
Error [VRCScoringPlugin.cc:88] Failed to find atlas
[ INFO] [1382118350.431597486]: atlas model not in world file, spawning from ros param [robot_description].
[ INFO] [1382118350.436742717, 0.001000000]: atlas model pushed into gazebo spawn queue.
~~~

Looks like `VRCScoringPlugin` gives up on finding Atlas before `VRCPlugin` has managed to spawn it.

We should either make `VRCScoringPlugin` more persistent or (more likely) just disable it, as there's probably nobody depending on it any more.
content.html:
With 3.1.0, I see this in the startup sequence when running roslaunch drcsim_gazebo vrc_task_3.launch:

[ INFO] [1382118350.430409299]: Starting robot with BDI standing
Error [VRCScoringPlugin.cc:88] Failed to find atlas
[ INFO] [1382118350.431597486]: atlas model not in world file, spawning from ros param [robot_description].
[ INFO] [1382118350.436742717, 0.001000000]: atlas model pushed into gazebo spawn queue.

Looks like VRCScoringPlugin gives up on finding Atlas before VRCPlugin has managed to spawn it.

We should either make VRCScoringPlugin more persistent or (more likely) just disable it, as there's probably nobody depending on it any more.

Gazebo shouldn't be looking in there for a `model.config`.

values.title: Produce standalone worlds

content.raw:
Similar to what's done in pull request #408, we should produce standalone versions of each `foo.world` that's included in drcsim.  More or less, it would be replacing something like this:

~~~
    <plugin filename="libVRCPlugin.so" name="vrc_plugin">
      <atlas>
        <model_name>atlas</model_name>
        <pin_link>utorso</pin_link>
      </atlas>
      <drc_vehicle>
        <model_name>golf_cart</model_name>
        <seat_link>chassis</seat_link>
      </drc_vehicle>
      <drc_fire_hose>
        <fire_hose_model>fire_hose</fire_hose_model>
        <coupling_link>coupling</coupling_link>
        <standpipe_model>standpipe</standpipe_model>
        <spout_link>standpipe</spout_link>
        <thread_pitch>-1000</thread_pitch>
        <coupling_relative_pose>1.17038e-05 -0.125623 0.35 -0.0412152 -1.57078 1.61199</coupling_relative_pose>
      </drc_fire_hose>
    </plugin>
~~~

with something like this:

~~~
    <include>
      <uri>model://atlas</uri>
    </include>
~~~

Then anybody who can parse SDF/URDF can run those worlds.  For bonus points, extract the initial pose values from the associate `.launch` file.

values.title: Teleop Walk Mode based on AtllasSimInterfaceCommand message

content.raw:
Update / create new teleop walk mode based on [AtlasSimInterfaceCommand message](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/1ccfde1621e7e9555b1dc2d35877db60dcd39b81/atlas_msgs/msg/AtlasSimInterfaceCommand.msg?at=default).

 1. Teleport the robot to its new foot pose without changing joint configuration.
 1. Attach commanded foot to inertial world by fixed constraint.
 1. Disable collision checks and contact joints for corresponding foot (and all leg links) with other collision objects in the world.

Potential future improvement:  playback a predefined joint velocity trajectory for leg links from the pelvis down to mimic walking motion.
content.html:
Update / create new teleop walk mode based on AtlasSimInterfaceCommand message.

  1. Teleport the robot to its new foot pose without changing joint configuration.
  2. Attach commanded foot to inertial world by fixed constraint.
  3. Disable collision checks and contact joints for corresponding foot (and all leg links) with other collision objects in the world.

Potential future improvement: playback a predefined joint velocity trajectory for leg links from the pelvis down to mimic walking motion.

values.title: Multisense-SL URDF Compatibility

content.raw:
The Multisense-SL URDF used by drcsim does not match the Multisense-SL URDF shipped with the Carnegie Robotics ROS driver. This make it difficult to update the full Atlas URDF when running on hardware. Would it be possible to use the Multisense URDF (https://bitbucket.org/crl/multisense_ros/src/ed051d65ed9f5c3d01bc9ef48de65759518c212e/multisense_description/urdf/multisense.urdf?at=default)? Or, if that breaks the TF tree, meet somewhere in the middle and agree upon a standard Multisense-SL URDF convention.

Matt Alvarado

Engineer at Carnegie Robotics

values.title: Provide correct meshes for upper leg/thigh protection grating

content.raw: The protection grating on the upper leg of the atlas model (also the v3 model) is far too large and useless for performing any kind of (self) collision estimation, as the robot self collides all the time. The grating is much smaller on the real system.

values.title: Update Multisense ladar and camera values to match hardware

content.raw:
The real ladar covers 270 degrees (rather than 180) and the real camera resolutions are at 1024x544.  Please update the multisense_v3 urdf to match these values.  This is also mentioned is #386.

Attached is an updated urdf with changes for the camera & ladar.

values.title: Allow saving of world with current robot pose

content.raw:
Because of the way that we spawn the Atlas robot into the world, the usual Save mechanism doesn't preserve the current pose.  That would be useful when testing certain sub-tasks within a world.  An example is having the robot in the vehicle.

It might be as easy as providing scripts to grab the current pose and save it to a file (e.g., rosparam-compatible YAML) and then push that pose back on a later launch.  Dealing with the robot being pinned somewhere (e.g., in the vehicle) would require a bit more work, but perhaps a similar trick can work: the script could record the parent/offest of the pin joint.
content.html:
Because of the way that we spawn the Atlas robot into the world, the usual Save mechanism doesn't preserve the current pose. That would be useful when testing certain sub-tasks within a world. An example is having the robot in the vehicle.

It might be as easy as providing scripts to grab the current pose and save it to a file (e.g., rosparam-compatible YAML) and then push that pose back on a later launch. Dealing with the robot being pinned somewhere (e.g., in the vehicle) would require a bit more work, but perhaps a similar trick can work: the script could record the parent/offest of the pin joint.

values.title: Support mixed-mode simulation with hardware in the loop

content.raw: A DRC team asks for: The ability to move easily between simulation and software is important.  It would be nice to do that selectively, e.g. move to the real atlas mechanical system and use simulated visual sensors.
content.html: A DRC team asks for: The ability to move easily between simulation and software is important. It would be nice to do that selectively, e.g. move to the real atlas mechanical system and use simulated visual sensors.

values.title: Message header timestamps should be relative to the epoch

content.raw:
According to [std_msgs/msg/Header.msg](https://github.com/ros/std_msgs/blob/groovy-devel/msg/Header.msg), the time stamp in the header of ros messages should be relative to the epoch. However, there are several messages in drcsim that populate this field with the current simulation time. This caused me some headaches today when trying to plot some drcsim bag files with rqt_plot.

[imu message](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/1f290ef5f80b365da499ef1ec62e110dbd616d0e/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-1798)

[atlas_state message](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/1f290ef5f80b365da499ef1ec62e110dbd616d0e/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-2524)

[this is where the current simulation time is used](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/1f290ef5f80b365da499ef1ec62e110dbd616d0e/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-854)

Of course, it won't be easy, since we're currently counting on the header timestamps to [compute synchronization delay](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/1f290ef5f80b365da499ef1ec62e110dbd616d0e/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-2121).
content.html:
According to std_msgs/msg/Header.msg, the time stamp in the header of ros messages should be relative to the epoch. However, there are several messages in drcsim that populate this field with the current simulation time. This caused me some headaches today when trying to plot some drcsim bag files with rqt_plot.

imu message

atlas_state message

this is where the current simulation time is used

Of course, it won't be easy, since we're currently counting on the header timestamps to compute synchronization delay.

content.raw: From a DRC team: The total mass is off by 10kg, so we suspect that a lot of the parameters are off, but we have very little means to measure or test them.

values.title: Nightly builds are broken

content.raw: The drcsim-nightly build cannot be installed because sdformat-nightly conflicts with ros-groovy-gazebo-plugins / ros-groovy-gazebo-ros / gazebo-current / sdformat. If drcsim-nightly depends on ros-groovy-gazebo-*, then it has to use sdformat and gazebo-current instead of sdformat-nightly and gazebo-nightly.

If drcsim-nightly depends on ros-groovy-gazebo-*, then it has to use sdformat and gazebo-current instead of sdformat-nightly and gazebo-nightly.

values.title: ROS commands don't match the actual iRobot hands

content.raw:
Migrated from pull request #395, originally posted by @mdfloyd

I've been playing with the iRobot hands in Gazebo, and have noticed that the ROS commands don't match the actual iRobot hands. From the real iRobot hands documetation (and experiment): For posititons 1-4: 3500 to put finger approx 90 degrees, 6000 to close gently, 7000 to close finger tightly. For spread (5th position) 8.533 ticks per degree: 768 is 90 degree T grip, 512 rotates the fingers 60 degrees for a spherical grasp. The ROS commands for running the Gazebo iRobot hands are much larger by at least an order of magnitude.

values.title: Accurate models for Atlas, iRobot and Sandia without adjustments for simulation stability should be available

content.raw:
When looking at the iRobot models we saw that the fingers were way heavier than realistically possible  (6.5 kg for just the fingers, because every link is assumed to be 100g). 

For accurate control of the physical Atlas, it is necessary to have an accurate robot model, both masses and inertia, without taking into account simulation stability.
